title: What's News --  Business & Finance
text:
Robinhood CEO Tenev offered an apology during a congressional hearing for the firm's decision to temporarily curb trading in some stocks, including GameStop, on Jan. 28 amid extraordinary volatility.

---

Walmart said it would raise wages for about 425,000 of its U.S. employees, as the retailer reported strong holiday sales but predicted slower growth and higher spending this year.

---

Initial jobless claims rose during the first half of February, pausing a downward trend that pointed to an improving labor market.

---

U.S. stocks dropped, with the S&P 500 and Dow both retreating 0.4%, while the Nasdaq shed 0.7%.

---

Volkswagen is considering listing as much as 25% of Porsche, a move analysts say could boost the market value of the entire VW group.

---

IBM is exploring a potential sale of its IBM Watson Health business as the tech giant looks to streamline.

---

Australians were caught off guard by Facebook's move to pull news from its platform in a spat with the government over payment for content.

Facebook has taken steps to prevent it from collecting sensitive personal data through apps but should do more, a New York regulator said.

---

Quibi is trying to force executives at Elliott to explain whether the hedge fund's involvement in financing a patent suit against it was motivated by a relationship between Elliott's founder and a colleague.
